titlestmt.titleproper: John Linnell, Tracings of Illustrations by William Blake for Dante's Divina Commedia.
Linnell (John) Tracings of illustrations by William Blake for Dante's Divina Commedia.
titlestmt.author: Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday March 22, 2019 at 03:00

did.unittitle: Tracings of illustrations by William Blake for Dante's Divina Commedia.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of a series of tracings by John Linnell of 99 of the 102 drawings made by William Blake to illustrate Dante's Divina Commedia.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Jared Eliot Associates, 1939.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Hell, 1831. II. Purgatory, 1831. III. Paradise, 1831.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Linnell (1792-1882), English painter and engraver.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John Linnell, Tracings of Illustrations by William Blake for Dante's Divina Commedia. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of a series of tracings made by John Linnell of 99 of the 102 drawings he commissioned from William Blake to illustrate Dante's Divina Commedia . Blake created his ink and watercolor drawings between 1824 and his death in 1827, and Linnell made his tracings in January and February 1831. The drawings are iron-gall ink on tracing paper, measure 44.6 x 56.2 cm and smaller, and are mounted on sheets of heavy paper measuring 61 x 48 cm. Most of the drawings have canto numbers from Dante's poem.

References given after drawing titles are to Paintings and Drawings of William Blake , by Martin Butlin (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1981). Missing from the set are tracings of Blake's images number 12, "First Version of Cerberus" (Butlin 812.12), number 15, "The Goddess of Fortune" (Butlin 812.16), and number 50, "The Punishment of the Thieves" (Butlin 812.102).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The John Linnell Tracings of Illustrations by William Blake for Dante's Divina Commedia is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.
